item.title: The Helton Howe Trace Formula
item.description:
We present a proof of a simple version of the Helton-Howe trace formula (for a more general version of this result, one should consult the original paper). Consider the Hardy space $H^2(\mathbb{D})$. There is a natural inclusion of $H^2(\mathbb{D})$ into $L^2(\mathbb{T})$, given by the restriction $f\mapsto f\vert_{\mathbb{T}}$. Let $\mathbb{P}_{H^2} : L^2(\mathbb{T}) \to H^2(\mathbb{D})$ denote the orthogonal projection of $L^2(\mathbb{T})$ into $H^2(\mathbb{D})$. Now, given $P \in \mathbb{C}[z,z^{-1}]$, we define the Toeplitz operator with principal symbol $P$ by $$T_P f(z) = \mathbb{P}_{H^2} \left[ P(z)f(z)\right],$$ for $f \in H^2(\mathbb{D})$. It is clear that the commutator of any two such operators operators is trace-class (it is even of finite rank). The Helton-Howe formula tells us that, given $P,Q \in \mathbb{C}[z,z^{-1}]$, $$\text{tr } [T_P, T_Q] = \frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{|z| = 1} P(z) Q'(z) dz = \frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{\mathbb{D}} dP \wedge dQ$$ The last equality is immediate from Stokes' theorem; the interesting equality is the first. Let $T_z$ denote the Toeplitz operator of multiplication by $z$ (this is just the shift operator in the Hardy space), and $T^*_z$ its adjoint (note that $T^*_z = T_{1/z}$). If $P = \sum_k P_k z^k \in \mathbb{C}[z,z^{-1}]$, then its corresponding Toeplitz operator may be written as $$T_P = \sum_{k\geq 0} P_k T_z^k + \sum_{k<0} P_k {T_z^{*}}^k.$$ Clearly, ${T_z^*}^n{T_z}^n = I$; on the other hand, ${T_z}^n{T_z^*}^n = I - \mathbb{P}_n$, where $\mathbb{P}_n$ is the orthogonal projector onto the subspace $E_n:=\text{span}$ {$1,z, …,z^{n-1}$}. This observation allows us to compute that $\text{tr }[{T_z^*}^n,{T_z}^n] = \text{tr } \mathbb{P}_n = n$. Now, if $n \neq m$, one finds by direct computation that $\text{tr }[{T_z^*}^m,{T_z}^n] = 0$. Thus, $\text{tr }[{T_z^*}^m,{T_z}^n] = n\delta_{n,m}$. If $P, Q \in \mathbb{C}[z,z^{-1}]$, and $P = \sum_k P_k z^k$, $Q = \sum_k Q_k z^k$, then $$= \sum_{n,m \geq 0} (P_{-n}Q_m - Q_{-n}P_m) [{T_z^*}^n,{T_z}^m];$$ taking traces yields $$\begin{aligned} \text{tr } [T_P,T_Q] &= \sum_{n,m \geq 0} (P_{-n}Q_m - Q_{-n}P_m) \text{tr } [{T_z^*}^n,{T_z}^m] \\\
&= \sum_{n,m \geq 0} (P_{-n}Q_m - Q_{-n}P_m) n\delta_{n,m} = \sum_{n\geq 0} n(P_{-n}Q_n - Q_{-n}P_n)\\\
&= \sum_{n}n P_{-n}Q_n. \end{aligned}$$ On the other hand, by residue theorem, $$\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{|z| = 1} P(z) Q'(z) dz &= \frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{|z| = 1} \sum_{\ell}\left(\sum_n nP_{\ell - n} Q_n \right) z^{\ell-1} dz\\\
&= \sum_{\ell}\left(\sum_n nP_{\ell - n} Q_n \right) \delta_{\ell,0}\\\
&= \sum_{n}n P_{-n}Q_n. \end{aligned}$$ Comparing the results of these two computations concludes the proof.

item.title: A short Introduction to the Theta Functions
item.description: The theory of theta function plays an important role in finding exact (quasi-) periodic solutions to the nonlinear PDEs. In this talk, we will introduce first the concepts of Riemannâ€™s theta function (with characteristics) and Jacobiâ€™s theta function. Then some of the simplest properties of those theta functions will be presented. If time permits, we will discuss a little bit about algebraic-geometry methods of constructing exact solution to KP equation.ðŸ˜„

item.title: A Survey of Equilibrium in the Plane
item.description:
Title: A survey of equilibrium in the plane

Speaker: Nathan Hayford

Date: Friday, September 4th

Time: 11:00am

Abstract: Finding equilibria of charge distributions in the plane is a classical problem, which has found numerous applications in many other areas of mathematics and physics, including approximation theory, random matrices, quantum gravity, and integrable systems, among others. In this talk, I will survey some classical results from the theory of equilibrium distributions (using the language of potential theory), and provide some physical intuition for why such formulas hold. We will consider equilibrium with and without external fields. Furthermore, I will discuss some of the more modern applications of the subject; in particular, I will sketch how the equilibrium measures help us describe the asymptotics of certain families of orthogonal polynomials, as well how such problems appear in integrable systems, if time permits.

Link to zoom meeting: https://zoom.us/j/93365223865 Video: Youtube.

item.title: The Nevanlinna-Pick Interpolation Problem
item.description:
Title: The Nevanlinna-Pick Interpolation Problem

Speaker: John Kyei

Date: Thursday, July 2nd

Time: 2:00pm

Abstract: In this presentation, I will give an introductory discussion on the general Nevanlina-Pick Interpolation problem . Formulation of the Pick Problem and the nature of solutions to the Extremal Pick Problem. Subsequently, Nevalinna Formulation. We will also look at the Finite Blaschke Products, Basic analytic and algebraic properties such as the characterizations of holomorphic functions on the disk, approximation and Differentiation of the Finite Blaschke Product.

Link to Zoom Meeting: https://zoom.us/j/99109270972

Video: Google

Slides: Google

item.title: Riemann Hilbert Problem
item.description:
Title: Introduction to the Riemann-Hilbert Problem in $L^p$-space.
Speaker: Fudong Wang.
Date: Thursday, January $23^{rd}$
Time: 11:00am
Place: CIS 1023
Abstract: We will first introduce some fundamental results about the Cauchy operator. Base on the Cauchy operator, we will make it precise what is the RHP and what is the solution to an RHP. Then we will talk about the two types of inhomogeneous Riemann-Hilbert problems and establish the equivalence between them. Finally, a uniqueness theorem of RHP in $L^p$ will be given. If time permits, its application to the inverse scattering theory will be mentioned too.
